SafetyInspectionBy: NV Board for the Regulation of Liq. Petroleum Gas

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Background and Corporate Commitment to Safety

At the Reno NV facility we handle propane that is recognized by the EPA as a regulated, flammable substance.  The same properties that make propane valuable as a fuel also make it necessary to practice certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent leaks, spills and accidents.  First and foremost in our operations are the efforts undertaken to ensure employee and contractor safety while on site as well as to minimize the risk exposure for the surrounding communities.  It is our company policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations.

As a corporation, AmeriGas staffs a professional Safety Department at our Corporate Headquarters in King of Prussia, Pennsylvania.  AmeriGas also has seven Regional Logistics Managers, a Terminal Operations Manager, a Safety and Technology Manager and a Supply and Logistics Safety Manager strategically located throughout the United States. These safety professionals are able to immediately respond to a serious incident and provide technical expertise to emergency response agencies as needed at the scene of the incident.  AmeriGas also maintains an around the clock Emergency Communications Center, which handles all after-hours and emergency calls from around the country.  Located in Rocklin, California, the ECC has the ability to contact AmeriGas field personnel, as well as Chemtrec, on any type of incident encountered at any AmeriGas location or by AmeriGas customers.   

The primary purpose of the facility is to store and distribute propane to AmeriGas retail facilities and wholesale customers.  Propane is received by rail cars then distributed to the customers by truck transports. Access to the site is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and contractors by the use of perimeter fencing and controlled gate access.


Accidental Release Prevention Policies and Practices

The site and the company continually strive to impro

ve operations performance including the prevention of incidents, injuries and releases at the facility.  Primary elements of this continuous improvement effort include making capital improvements to the facility as required, maintaining up to date procedures and continual training of personnel in both regulatory and job specific subject matter.  The integrity and reliability of major equipment, including pumps, compressors, pipelines and storage tanks is assured through periodic inspection and preventive maintenance practices.  The chemicals handled do not present significant internal corrosion hazards and corrosion to external surfaces of pipelines and storage tanks is minimized via extensive inspection and painting programs.  

As important as those previously mentioned items are, emergency shutdown systems and portable fire extinguishers are also available on site.  The emergency shutdown systems include the ability to activate via remote control, positive shutoff valves designed to shutdown the affected equipment or isolate a problem once it is detected.  

This distribution and storage facility is subject to and abides by OSHAÂ¿s Process Safety Management (PSM) rule for sites handling hazardous chemicals.  In addition, the site complies with EPAÂ¿s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and all other applicable federal, state and local codes.  When built, this facility was designed in accordance with NFPA-58.  

All of our AmeriGas transport drivers are trained in the terminalÂ¿s loading & emergency action plan procedures and future plans include driver certification using the National Propane Gas AssociationÂ¿s (NPGA) Certified Employee Training Program (CETP).


Five Year Accident History

This facility has not had an accident or release meeting RMP criteria within the last five years.


Emergency Response Program

Though the site is classified as a non-responding facility, it maintains an Emergency Action Plan (EAP), complying with state of Nevada regulations.

Both plans include procedures for notification of the local fire, law enforcement and medical organizations.  Notification of potentially affected neighbors would be coordinated through the fire department or law enforcement after consultation with site personnel.  Should as actual incident occur, the plans give guidance to employees on how to respond if it is a minor problem and easily controlled on site.  Larger emergencies require assistance from the local emergency response organizations and employees are knowlegeable as to when that outside assistance is required.  

The plans are reviewed periodically to ensure that they remains up-to-date, reflecting current activities on site and employees are trained on their responsibilities in an emergency to ensure prompt response.  The ERP and EAP are based upon the following guidelines and standards:

1) NPGA LP-Gas Safety Handbooks:  Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures and How To Control LP-Gas Leaks and Fires.
2) OSHAÂ¿s Occupational Safety and Health Standards for General Industry, specifically: 29 CFR 1910.38, Â¿Emergency Action PlansÂ¿, 29CFR 1910.39, Â¿Fire Prevention PlansÂ¿, 29 CFR 1910.119, Â¿Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous ChemicalsÂ¿ and 29 CFR 1910.120, Â¿Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency ResponseÂ¿
3) National Fire Protection Association Guidelines, NFPA 58, Â¿Liquified Petroleum Gas CodeÂ¿ and NFPA 54, Â¿National Fuel Gas CodeÂ¿.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The facility is engaged in adding additional storage at this location. The Permit to Construct has not been issued at the time of this RMP, nor has a Permit to Operate. We are working with Nevada Chemical Accident Prevention board to obtain the necessary permits and an updated RMP will be done when changes are completed. Existing equipment, such as the main compressors, receive an annual maintenance overhaul to keep it running safely and efficiently.  In addition, the siteÂ¿s Regional Logistics Manager is
planning to become certified to teach and proctor future CETP training modules.
